title: LNER Class J94
text:
The <a href="London%20and%20North%20Eastern%20Railway">London and North Eastern Railway</a> (LNER) J94 Class is a class of <a href="steam%20locomotive">steam locomotive</a> that was formed when 75 former <a href="Hunslet%20Austerity%200-6-0ST">"Austerity" 0-6-0ST</a>s were purchased by the LNER in 1946 from the <a href="War%20Department%20%28UK%29">War Department</a>.
Overview.
The LNER had had trials with one in November 1945 and bought 75 of them in 1946, numbering them 8006-80. All entered <a href="British%20Railways">British Railways</a> (BR) service in 1948. BR added 60000 to their numbers so they became 68006-80, and classified them 4F.
They were used for shunting in docks, and other similar work where their short wheelbase meant they could negotiate sharp curves. They were used on the <a href="Cromford%20and%20High%20Peak%20Railway">Cromford and High Peak Railway</a> in <a href="Derbyshire">Derbyshire</a>, where they displaced the ex-<a href="North%20London%20Railway">North London Railway</a> <a href="NLR%20Class%2075">Class 75</a> class 2F s.
They were withdrawn between 1960 and 1967. A few were sold into industrial use with the <a href="National%20Coal%20Board">National Coal Board</a> (who had several other Austerities) and others.
Preservation.
Two, BR Nos 68077 and 68078 and have been preserved. In addition a large number of Austerities that were used in industry and have survived to preservation. Several of these have been disguised as BR locomotives.
Models.
The erstwhile Rosebud <a href="Kitmaster">Kitmaster</a> company produced an unpowered polystyrene injection moulded model kit for <a href="00%20gauge">00 gauge</a>, which went on sale in Spring 1961. In early 1963, the Kitmaster brand was sold by its parent company (Rosebud Dolls) to <a href="Airfix">Airfix</a>, who transferred the moulding tools to their own factory; they re-introduced some of the former Kitmaster range, including this locomotive. The tool (for this model) was destroyed in a fire at the premises of Dapol Model Railways Ltd in <a href="Winsford">Winsford</a>, <a href="Cheshire">Cheshire</a> so that <a href="Dapol">Dapol</a> were unable to produce further kits after their first two production runs totalling 4000 kits after acquisition of the former Airfix moulds.
